questions.text: A previously healthy 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 3-week history of fever, fatigue, and malaise. His mother says she noticed a significant decrease in his appetite and overall activity level. He is homeschooled and has had no sick contacts. There are no pets at home, but he often visits a feline animal shelter where his mother volunteers. Temperature is 38.4°C (101.2°F). Physical examination shows a 1-cm papular lesion on the back of the right hand. He also has tender, bulky lymphadenopathy of the axillae and groin. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antibiotic treatment with doxycycline is recommended for immunocompromised individuals with localized CSD and for most patients with extranodal CSD. This patient has localized CSD and is not immunocompromised, so doxycycline is not the most appropriate antibiotic therapy. Additionally, if antibiotic treatment is necessary for a young child with extranodal CSD and/or immunocompromised status, erythromycin should be considered instead of doxycycline to avoid its possible side effects (e.g., tooth enamel hypoplasia, permanent tooth discoloration).

B) INCORRECT:

Pyrimethamine is an antiprotozoal drug used in the treatment of toxoplasmosis, which is extremely rare in immunocompetent hosts. If symptoms occur, they are usually limited to painless, cervical lymphadenopathy, as opposed to the findings in this patient (papule on the hand, diffuse lymphadenopathy).

C) INCORRECT:

Itraconazole can be used for treating sporotrichosis caused by the fungus Sporothrix schenckii, which is usually transmitted through small skin lesions when handling soil or moss. The most common presentation is a papule that may ulcerate, usually without any systemic symptoms. In rare cases, sporotrichosis may spread to other organs such as the lungs and cause systemic symptoms, but this almost exclusively occurs in immunocompromised patients.

D) CORRECT:

Antibiotic treatment is usually not required in immunocompetent patients with localized CSD because the infection is self-limited. However, azithromycin can be used to reduce lymphadenopathy and illness duration. Treatment with erythromycin or doxycycline is recommended for immunocompromised individuals with localized CSD and patients with extranodal CSD.
Image Description:

A solitary reddish-purple papule on an erythematous base is visible on the patient's right thenar eminence.

This appearance is typical of cat scratch disease, i.e., infection with Bartonella henselae.

E) INCORRECT:

Streptomycin is an aminoglycoside effective against Yersinia pestis, which is spread through flea bites and causes the plague. The most common subtype is bubonic plague, which also manifests with fever and weakness, followed by tender lymphadenopathy. Lymphadenopathy indicates that the infection has spread from the initial entry point on the hand throughout the body. In the case of plague, the presence of lymphadenopathy would indicate a severe and systemic course, often with gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., diarrhea, vomiting), followed by shock and multiple organ failure.
questions.hint: The cutaneous lesion on the patient's hand combined with bulky lymphadenopathy and a history of exposure to cats raises suspicion for localized cat scratch disease (CSD).

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He has had a progressively increasing swelling on the nape of the neck for 2 months. He has not had fever or any discharge from the swelling. He underwent a colectomy for colon cancer at 43 years of age. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and osteoarthritis. Current medications include insulin glargine, metformin, enalapril, and naproxen. He has worked as a landscaper for the past 16 years and frequently plays golf. He appears healthy. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 130/86 mm Hg. Examination of the neck shows a 2.5-cm firm, mobile, and painless nodule. The skin over the nodule cannot be pinched. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A photograph of the lesion is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Actinic keratoses (AK) are precancerous skin lesions caused by ultraviolet light exposure and are commonly found in light-skinned people over 50 years of age. AKs begin as a small lesion with a rough surface (“sandpaper-like texture”) and later grow to become scaly and crusted. These lesions can also transform into squamous cell carcinoma, a phenomenon particularly common in patients with multiple AKs. This patient's lesion does not have the typical appearance of an AK.
Image Description:

Frontal and parietal scalp of a male older adult

Multiple, partially confluent, hyperpigmented and hypopigmented macules of different size are visible. Some of these lesions have scaling, and some are covered in yellow to black-brown crusts.

These findings are characteristic of actinic keratosis.

B) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is consistent with an epidermoid cyst, a nontender, dome-shaped, slow-growing nodule that arises from the epidermis and contains keratin. Common locations for epidermoid cysts include the neck, face, head, back, and genital area. These lesions can be distinguished from those arising below the epidermis, as the overlying skin cannot be pinched.

Epidermoid cysts are one of the common cutaneous findings in patients with Gardner syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Dermatofibromas are small, skin-colored growths that most commonly develop on the lower extremities. Because dermatofibromas arise from the dermis, the epidermis overlying the lesion is pinchable and produces a central dimple (Fitzpatrick sign). Since the skin overlying this patient's nodule cannot be pinched, it is unlikely to be a dermatofibroma.
Image Description:

A solitary, pigmented, firm circular lesion is visible. Upon pinching of the lesion, the overlaying skin retracts inwards (dimple sign).

This appearance is suggestive of a dermatofibroma, which usually manifests as a nodule.

D) INCORRECT:

Lipomas are painless, slow-growing, mobile nodules that are rubbery rather than firm (they are made of mature fat cells). Unlike this patient's nodule, lipomas do not arise from the cutaneous layers; the overlying skin can be pinched.
Image Description:

There is a solitary soft subcutaneous nodule under normal-appearing skin. If the nodule is pushed by gently sliding a finger over the edge, the lipoma tends to slip away from the examining finger (slippage/slip sign).

E) INCORRECT:

Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is the second most common skin cancer after basal cell carcinoma. The classic presentation of SCC is a painless, slow-growing, nonhealing ulcer with everted edges. The underlying structure that ulcerates can range from plaque-like to verrucous. Although a potential malignancy must be considered, this patient's nonulcerated nodule does not fit the classic presentation of SCC.
Image Description:

A solitary ulcer, approx. 2 cm in diameter, is visible on the lower lip. The inferior aspect of the ulcer appears hyperkeratotic.

This finding is highly suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma. Oral squamous cell carcinoma most commonly affects the lower lip because of its direct exposure to sunlight.
questions.hint: This patient's nodule arises from the layers of the skin, as it cannot be pinched.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of a 1-month history of a painful ulcer on her face. She has developed painful sunburns in the past with minimal UV exposure. Examination of the skin shows a 2-cm ulcerated nodule on the left cheek. There are scaly, hyperpigmented papules and plaques over the skin of the entire body. Ophthalmologic examination shows decreased visual acuity, clouded corneas, and limbal injection. Examination of a biopsy specimen from the facial lesion shows poorly-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. Impairment of which of the following proteins is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

UV radiation results in dimer formation of neighboring pyrimidine bases, most commonly thymine. These bulky pyrimidine dimers induce helix distortion and can disrupt DNA replication. Dimers are usually repaired by nucleotide excision repair in the G1 phase of the cell cycle, in which the damaged oligonucleotides are first recognized and then excised. The process is carried out by excision endonucleases. DNA polymerase and ligase then fill and reseal the resulting gap. Mutations in any of these endonucleases can lead to extreme UV sensitivity and xeroderma pigmentosum.

B) INCORRECT:

Rb nuclear protein is a tumor suppressor gene responsible for the regulation of entry into cell division. It has no role in DNA damage repair. Mutations in this gene lead to the development of retinoblastoma or osteosarcoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Base-specific glycosylases are vital enzymes for the process of base-excision repair, which occurs throughout the cell cycle and is necessary for the removal and replacement of incorrect or damaged bases in a single strand. Base excision repair begins with the base-specific glycosylase recognizing and removing the damaged base from the underlying backbone, leaving behind an abasic site (AP-site). An AP endonuclease or AP lyase then cleaves the AP-site. DNA polymerase-β fills the gap and DNA ligase seals it.

D) INCORRECT:

DNA helicase is normally involved in DNA replication, not repair. However, some members of the helicase family (such as the BLM gene) provide stability to unwound DNA duplexes during recombination-specific repair and replication. Mutations in this gene lead to a rare autosomal-recessive disorder called Bloom syndrome, which may present with photosensitivity and an increased risk of developing cancers. However, there are usually further signs such as small stature, distinctive facial features (e.g., long face, small lower jaw, prominent nose and ears), café-au-lait spots, and telangiectasias.

E) INCORRECT:

A mutation in the ATM gene results in a defective ATM serine/threonine kinase and ataxia-telangiectasia syndrome. ATM serine/threonine kinase is normally responsible for activating the downstream signaling pathways necessary to repair double-stranded DNA breaks by nonhomologous end joining but has no role in the detection or repair of UV-induced DNA damage.
questions.hint: This young patient has a history of extreme sensitivity to light and presents with squamous cell carcinoma, several ocular abnormalities, and multiple hyperpigmented patches that likely represent precancerous lesions. These clinical findings are consistent with xeroderma pigmentosum, a rare, autosomal-recessive disease in which the ability to repair UV-induced DNA damage is defective.

questions.text: A 28-year-old African American woman delivers her first child at 39 weeks' gestation. On examination, the newborn's skin and hair have a milky white color, and his eyes are light blue with a slight reddish hue. A skin biopsy shows a normal number of epidermal and follicular melanocytes. The physician advises the parents that the child will need a comprehensive eye examination and genetic testing to establish the suspected diagnosis. A defect in which of the following enzymes is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A defect in phenylalanine hydroxylase is responsible for classic phenylketonuria (PKU), a disorder characterized by phenylalanine accumulation and tyrosine deficiency. If untreated, patients with PKU develop generalized hypopigmentation, as seen here, because tyrosine is a precursor of melanin and high phenylalanine levels inhibit the enzyme responsible for melanin synthesis. However, the clinical features of PKU are not seen at birth because the fetus obtains tyrosine from maternal blood, and excess phenylalanine (as well as its toxic byproducts) is removed by the placenta. The features of PKU (e.g., hypopigmentation, seizures, intellectual disability, a musty odor) typically develop during infancy following the initiation of feeding.

B) INCORRECT:

A defect in DOPA decarboxylase leads to a deficiency in dopamine, an important neurotransmitter in the central nervous system. During infancy, patients with DOPA decarboxylase deficiency present with hypotonia, athetosis, lethargy, and poor feeding, none of which are seen in this patient. This patient's presentation is not consistent with a defect in DOPA decarboxylase.

C) INCORRECT:

Tyrosine kinase is primarily involved in signal transduction and cell proliferation. Defects in tyrosine kinase can result, e.g., in Bruton agammaglobulinemia (loss of function mutation of the BTK), chronic myeloid leukemia (gain of function mutation of BCR-ABL), or multiple endocrine neoplasia (gain of function mutation of RET). This patient's condition is caused by a defect in a different enzyme.

D) CORRECT:

Tyrosinase is a copper-containing enzyme in melanocytes that produces melanin from dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA), which is derived from tyrosine by the action of tyrosine hydroxylase or tyrosinase itself. Tyrosinase is encoded by the TYR gene on chromosome 11; a defect in this gene is responsible for oculocutaneous albinism type 1 (OCA1), which manifests as hypopigmentation of the hair, skin, and irides with a normal density of melanocytes on skin biopsy, as seen here. The neurological and physical development of infants with OCA1 is similar to that of normal infants, but they have an increased risk of skin cancer and visual abnormalities and therefore need to undergo skin and eye screenings periodically.
Image Description:

Overview of the biosynthesis and breakdown of the catecholamines dopamine, norepinephrine and epinephrine, starting with the amino acid phenylalanine and showing enzymes (blue text) and cofactors (blue highlighting).

The glucocorticoid cortisol induces expression of phenylethanolamine N-methyltransferase and thus the conversion of norepinephrine to epinephrine. The drug carbidopa (used, e.g., in Parkinson disease) inhibits DOPA decarboxylase and thus the peripheral conversion of L-DOPA to dopamine.

Congenital diseases may occur due to enzyme deficiencies, as shown here for phenylketonuria (1; defect in phenylalanine hydroxylase), albinism (2; defect in tyrosinase), and alkaptonuria (3; defect in homogentisate oxidase).

E) INCORRECT:

A defect in homogentisate oxidase (alkaptonuria) leads to the accumulation of homogentisic acid and manifests as ochronosis, a blue-black discoloration of the skin, cartilage, tendons, and body fluids that come in contact with air (e.g., urine). The generalized hypopigmentation in this patient is not consistent with a defect in homogentisate oxidase.

F) INCORRECT:

Phenylethanolamine-N-methyltransferase (PNMT) is mainly found in the adrenal medulla and catalyzes the formation of epinephrine from norepinephrine. A deficiency of this enzyme is not the cause of this newborn's condition.
questions.hint: Dihydroxyphenalanine (DOPA), an intermediate compound in the synthesis of catecholamines, serves as one of the substrates of this enzyme. A deficiency of this enzyme will result in oculocutaneous albinism, as seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman comes to the physician because of multiple skin lesions over her legs for one month. She reports that the lesions are red, dry, and intensely pruritic. She has had 3 episodes in the past 2 years with similar lesions that resolved spontaneously after a couple of months. She mentions that she has been using a moisturizer daily because of her dry skin. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable and she takes no medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. A photograph of one of the lesions is shown. Gram stain of a skin swab of the lesion and skin scraping for fungal hyphae are negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Nummular eczema (NE) is a chronic, relapsing inflammatory skin condition characterized by multiple well-demarcated, round, dry, and intensely pruritic erythematous plaques typically affecting the extremities. NE is thought to be caused by an immunological hypersensitivity reaction due to xerosis and damage to the epidermal lipid barrier, but the pathogenesis is not completely understood. Patient history, clinical examination findings, and negative skin scrapings for mycology are sufficient to confirm the diagnosis of NE. Management includes measures to help prevent dry skin (e.g., application of moisturizer, use of mild soaps) and topical anti-inflammatory agents (e.g., corticosteroids, tacrolimus, pimecrolimus).

B) INCORRECT:

Allergic contact dermatitis (ACD) can manifest with pruritic and erythematous plaques as a result of a delayed hypersensitivity reaction after exposure to certain substances, e.g., moisturizer, which this patient has reported using. In ACD, however, all areas of skin exposed to the allergen are typically involved.
Image Description:

Upper body of a man presenting with a severely pruritic rash after getting a henna tattoo on the right arm

An erythematous papulovesicular rash is visible over the chest and arms. The rash is most severe around the henna tattoo, which appears markedly erythematous.

This is the typical appearance of allergic contact dermatitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Atopic dermatitis (AD) is a chronic, relapsing inflammatory skin condition that may manifest with dry, pruritic, and erythematous plaques. However, the plaques seen in adult patients with AD are typically distributed along the flexural creases (e.g., cubital fossa, popliteal fossa). Moreover, most cases of AD develop before the age of 5 years, and patients with AD often have a history of asthma or allergic rhinitis.
Image Description:

Ill-defined, erythematous macules with excoriation (due to scratching) can be seen on the flexural surface of the knee.

D) INCORRECT:

Psoriasis is a chronic, relapsing inflammatory skin condition that can manifest with multiple, well-demarcated, pruritic, erythematous plaques. However, the plaques seen in psoriasis are usually not limited to the legs. Moreover, psoriasis plaques are typically associated with silvery-white scaling, which this patient does not have.
Image Description:

Extensor (dorsal) surface of the right forearm

Multiple well-demarcated, partially confluent, erythematous plaques with silver-white scaling are visible.

These patches are characteristic of plaque psoriasis, which typically occurs on extensor surfaces of the body.

E) INCORRECT:

Tinea corporis (TC) is a dermatophytic infection that can manifest with ring-shaped, pruritic, erythematous plaques. However, a skin scraping for mycology would reveal fungal hyphae. Moreover, TC does not typically resolve spontaneously, like this patient's previous episodes. Instead, topical antifungal treatment (e.g., miconazole, terbinafine) is usually required. Additionally, TC plaques are typically associated with central clearing and raised borders.
Image Description:

A round, well demarcated erythematous lesion with central scaling is visible. The border is raised with several pustules visible.

These features are characteristic of tinea corporis.
questions.hint: The photograph shows a 5 cm coin-shaped, erythematous scaly plaque.

questions.text: A 31-year-old man comes to the office because of a 1-week history of a bilateral pruritic rash on his hands and fingers. He says that he has had a similar rash several times during the past few years, mostly in late spring and summer. The previous rashes resolved spontaneously several weeks later with peeling skin. He has a history of dermatophyte infection of the feet, which was successfully treated with topical terbinafine. He has no known allergies. He works as a software engineer. He takes no medications. A photograph of his right index finger is shown. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hand eczema, which may be a manifestation of atopic dermatitis, usually causes severe pruritus. However, atopic hand eczema typically manifests as diffuse erythema and scaling on the dorsum of the hands, and is chronic rather than recurrent. In addition, this patient has no history of atopic dermatitis, allergy, or asthma, making atopic hand eczema unlikely.
Image Description:

Erythematous papules are visible on the dorsal aspect of the fingers and knuckles.

These findings are consistent with contact dermatitis or atopic dermatitis.

B) INCORRECT:

While palmoplantar pustulosis can manifest with recurrent, pruritic lesions on both hands, the lesions are pustular rather than vesicular, mostly affect the palms, and are usually also present on the soles of the feet. Moreover, the pustules in palmoplantar pustulosis usually dry and desquamate within days rather than weeks, resulting in hyperkeratosis and brown macules.

C) INCORRECT:

Tinea manuum is a dermatophyte infection of the hands that can cause recurrent episodes of pruritus. However, tinea manuum is typically unilateral and manifests with a dry, erythematous, and scaly palmar surface, and/or a round, erythematous plaque on the dorsum of the hand (vesicles and bullae may be present in some cases). Moreover, in most cases, tinea manuum occurs at the same time as tinea pedis (“two feet-one hand syndrome”), and while this patient has a history of tinea pedis, it is not currently present.
Image Description:

Localization: palm of the right hand

Lesion: dry skin, hyperkeratosis, and rhagades, particularly in the hand lines. Lesions usually start on one hand, but may spread to the other side.

Differential diagnosis: atopic eczema, palmoplantar eczema, psoriasis, and allergic contact dermatitis

D) CORRECT:

Dyshidrotic eczema is a condition of unknown etiology that is characterized by recurrent episodes of vesicular and/or bullous eruptions on the palms, sides of the fingers, and/or soles. Symptoms are often exacerbated by warm weather. The deep-seated vesicles and bullae typically persist for several weeks and then resolve with drying and desquamation. A history of dermatophyte infection, as seen in this patient, is a risk factor for dyshidrotic eczema; additional risk factors include atopic dermatitis, irritant contact dermatitis, and allergic contact dermatitis. Chronic dermatitis and secondary infection are potential complications.

Dyshidrotic eczema is typically managed using general measures (e.g., avoiding triggers, appropriate skin care); topical corticosteroids are used in mild cases that do not respond to general measures, and oral corticosteroids are used in severe cases.

E) INCORRECT:

While recurrent episodes of finger edema and vesicular eruptions are typical features of herpetic whitlow, the lesions seen in this condition are typically unilateral and painful rather than pruritic. In addition, symptoms such as fever and malaise are often present in herpetic whitlow, both of which are absent in this patient.
Image Description:

A cluster of three nonpurulent vesicles on an erythematous base is visible on the distal phalanx. The surrounding skin is intact.

This is the characteristic appearance of herpetic whitlow.
questions.hint: This patient has a recurrent, bilateral, pruritic vesicular rash affecting the hands and fingers. Although this patient's condition is usually self-limited, treatment with corticosteroids may be considered.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the physician because of fever and painful swelling in his right axilla for 1 week. He feels tired and reports a loss of appetite. He works in a garden center during weekdays and at a pet shop that sells various pet mammals and fish during the weekends. He smokes one pack of cigarettes daily and occasionally marijuana. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 95/min, and blood pressure is 131/85 mm Hg. Physical examination shows tender, erythematous, and fluctuant right axillary lymph node swelling with oozing purulent discharge. There is an erythematous papule on the right index finger. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely infectious agent?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Toxoplasma gondii is a parasite that is most commonly transmitted via the ingestion of cysts (e.g., from cat feces) and causes toxoplasmosis. Most immunocompetent individuals with toxoplasmosis are asymptomatic or have fever and lymphadenopathy, both of which are seen here. However, the adenopathy is typically nontender, bilateral, and affects the cervical lymph nodes, whereas this patient has unilateral, tender, suppurative, axillary lymphadenopathy. In addition, erythematous skin lesions are not characteristic of toxoplasmosis.

B) CORRECT:

Bartonella henselae is a gram‑negative bacterium that is commonly found in cats and transmitted to humans via a scratch or a bite. It can lead to a benign, self-limiting disease (i.e., cat scratch disease) or disseminated disease in immunocompromised patients (i.e., bacillary angiomatosis). This patient's exposure to animals at the pet shop puts him at risk for developing cat scratch disease, which initially manifests with fever, loss of appetite, and an erythematous, nontender cutaneous papule at the site of inoculation, all of which are seen here. Lymphadenopathy develops shortly after the initial symptoms, and is usually tender, unilateral, and localized near the site of the inoculation (most commonly in the axillary nodes).
Image Description:

A solitary reddish-purple papule on an erythematous base is visible on the patient's right thenar eminence.

This appearance is typical of cat scratch disease, i.e., infection with Bartonella henselae.

C) INCORRECT:

Vibrio vulnificus is a gram-negative bacillus that can be transmitted via contaminated seawater that has come into contact with open wounds. This patient's exposure to fish at the pet shop puts him at risk for developing a V. vulnificus infection, which can cause cellulitis and also manifest with an erythematous skin lesion, fever, and lymphadenopathy. However, suppuration of the lymph nodes is not characteristic of V. vulnificus cellulitis and the symptoms typically develop more acutely.

D) INCORRECT:

Pasteurella multocida is a gram‑negative coccobacillus that can cause cellulitis secondary to dog or cat bites. Although cellulitis might explain this patient's erythematous skin lesion, lymphadenopathy, and fever, it does not lead to suppuration of the lymph nodes and it typically manifests more acutely, making a different diagnosis more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Sporothrix schenckii is a dimorphic fungus that is found on vegetation and garden soil and leads to sporotrichosis, which initially manifests as an erythematous papule at the site of inoculation. However, most patients with sporotrichosis develop subcutaneous nodules and ulcers along the draining lymphatic vessels (nodular ascending lymphangitis) rather than isolated suppurative lymphadenopathy. In addition, sporotrichosis does not usually manifest with systemic symptoms such as fever and loss of appetite.
Image Description:

Photograph of the left arm of a patient

There are several large, nodular lesions on the left arm. The largest and most distal lesion is ulcerated. The chain-like pattern of these lesions follows a lymphocutaneous distribution.

This is the typical appearance of lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis.
questions.hint: Histopathological examination of the lesion will show necrotizing granulomas.

questions.text: A previously healthy 1-month-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because of a rash for the past day. She has had no fever, runny nose, vomiting, or diarrhea. Her parents say they have not used any new laundry detergents or cosmetics and that she has not been in contact with any animals. Two days ago, the family arrived in Miami to introduce the girl to her grandparents during the summer vacation. The parents report that they dressed her in several layers of clothing to protect her from direct sun exposure. She was born at term following an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery and is exclusively breastfed. Family history is unremarkable. Immunizations are up-to-date. She is at the 55th percentile for length and weight and at the 65th percentile for head circumference. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows multiple erythematous papules measuring 2–4 mm in diameter with background erythema in the axillae and on the neck and trunk. The oral mucosa appears normal. There is no cervical or axillary lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antihistamines (e.g., diphenhydramine) can be used to treat type I hypersensitivity reactions, which result in histamine release and can manifest with a pruritic, erythematous, papular rash. However, miliaria rubra is not histamine-mediated, so an antihistamine would not be appropriate.

B) INCORRECT:

Reassurance alone is appropriate for self-limited, asymptomatic rashes. However, this patient's rash is making her uncomfortable, and she would benefit from intervention to encourage resolution of the rash and prevention of its recurrence.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral acetaminophen can be used to treat fever or pain. This patient has not had any fever, and her discomfort is likely due to pruritus from miliaria rubra, which does not respond to treatment with acetaminophen.

D) INCORRECT:

Topical nystatin can be used to treat cutaneous candidiasis, which can manifest with an erythematous rash in the diaper or intertriginous areas after prolonged exposure to moisture. However, candidal intertrigo typically manifests with maceration, vesicles and pustules that easily rupture, and satellite lesions. Miliaria rubra does not have a fungal origin, so antifungal therapy is not indicated.

E) CORRECT:

Miliaria is often seen in hot and humid climates (e.g., Miami) and can occur in all ages but commonly affects children and infants. Miliaria rubra is the most prevalent form of miliaria and manifests with a pruritic, papulovesicular, erythematous rash, typically on the intertriginous areas of the groin, axillae, and neck. Management of miliaria rubra consists of measures to reduce sweating and occlusion of eccrine glands, such as keeping the patient in a cool environment, wearing breathable clothing (e.g., cotton), lightly scrubbing the skin to remove debris that can clog sweat glands, and, if nonpharmacologic measures fail to reduce the rash, administering topical steroids to decrease inflammation.
Image Description:

Multiple, partially confluent papules on erythematous skin are visible.
questions.hint: This patient developed an erythematous, papular rash after arriving in a hot and humid climate, which is characteristic of miliaria rubra.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman returns for follow-up of hypertension and diet-controlled type 2 diabetes. Her medications include amlodipine, aspirin, a multivitamin, and a fish oil supplement, all taken daily. She is a lifetime nonsmoker and drinks alcohol only occasionally. She reports eating a low-fat diet and exercising 3 to 4 days per week for 30 to 60 minutes at moderate intensity.
On examination, she is 163 cm tall and weighs 58 kg; her BMI is 21.8. Her seated blood pressure is 126/82 mm Hg, and her heart rate is 84 beats per minute. Her abdominal circumference is 82 cm. Her face and neck have a gaunt appearance with minimal to no subcutaneous fat pads, and her upper extremities are quite thin. She also has substantial excess fat around her hips, buttocks, and thighs. She has had this appearance since she was a child. Her thyroid gland is normal. There is no abdominal obesity and no violaceous striae. She has no rashes, acne, hirsutism, or acanthosis nigricans. Her neurologic examination is normal.
Fasting laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Glucose (mg/dL)
108
70–100


Glycated hemoglobin (%)
6.0
4.3–5.6


Total cholesterol (mg/dL)
202
125–200


LDL cholesterol (mg/dL)
90
<130


HDL cholesterol (mg/dL)
51
≥46


Triglycerides (mg/dL)
300
<150


Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An ovarian teratoma may cause ovarian torsion and manifest as a mass with associated abdominal or pelvic pain or ascites. It would not cause the phenotypic appearance described in this scenario.

B) INCORRECT:

Autoimmune polyendocrine syndrome is characterized by the overt presence of two or more of the following: Addison disease, type 1 diabetes, Hashimoto hypothyroidism, and primary ovarian insufficiency.

C) INCORRECT:

Cushing syndrome causes a characteristic appearance that includes moon facies, abnormal fat deposition in dorsocervical and supraclavicular fat pads, and central adiposity with peripheral muscle loss.

D) INCORRECT:

Anorexia nervosa is not associated with selective fat loss in some areas and weight gain in other areas.

E) CORRECT:

The phenotypic appearance of fat loss in the face and neck with excess fat deposition in the hips, buttocks, and legs is characteristic of acquired partial lipodystrophy, the most commonly described type of lipodystrophy before the recognition of lipodystrophy in people with HIV.

Acquired partial lipodystrophy is rare and primarily affects women. Onset is generally before puberty, often before the age of 10. In contrast to other types of lipodystrophy that are associated with substantial fat loss, acquired partial lipodystrophy is associated with more-limited fat loss and is infrequently associated with diabetes mellitus and severe lipid abnormalities. There is no specific treatment for acquired partial lipodystrophy.

Lipodystrophy can also occur in people with HIV and is typically associated with the use of antiretroviral therapy.

Key learning point: The phenotypic appearance of fat loss in the face and neck with excess fat deposition in the hips and legs is suggestive of acquired partial lipodystrophy.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman reports having a “bruise” on her left breast for the past month. She has a history of stage IIA, node-positive, estrogen-receptor-positive invasive ductal carcinoma that was treated 7 years ago with chemotherapy, mastectomy, and radiation.
Physical examination reveals a 2.5-cm erythematous nodule 2 cm medial to her mastectomy scar (figure).
A mammogram of the right breast is negative for cancer, and an ultrasound of the left chest wall shows only an area of skin thickening at the site of the lesion.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hemangiomas are usually <2 cm in size and have visible feeder vessels.

B) INCORRECT:

The time frame from radiation therapy to the development of the nodule in this patient is inconsistent with normal post-radiation vascular changes.

C) INCORRECT:

Leukocytoclastic vasculitis does not manifest with a singular nodule and is typically associated with systemic symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Radiation recall dermatitis is an inflammatory skin reaction (most commonly, eczema) that occurs at the site of previous radiation exposure when a causative agent (often, chemotherapy) is introduced. This condition usually occurs with the first dose of the causative agent and is therefore unlikely in this patient, who is presenting with cutaneous symptoms 7 years after chemotherapy.

E) CORRECT:

Although rare among sarcomas, angiosarcomas have become increasingly important because of their association with radiation therapy, especially for breast cancer. Radiation-associated angiosarcoma typically manifests several years after therapy, with a cutaneous tumor that looks similar to a bruise or hematoma. In patients with primary breast cancer, latency is usually 5 to 7 years. Diffuse involvement and satellite nodules are common. Prognosis is usually poor, as local and distant recurrence is common. Surgical treatment, typically with mastectomy, is preferred.

Key learning point: A cutaneous nodule with a bruise-like appearance in a patient with previous radiation to the area is suspicious for radiation-associated angiosarcoma.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old woman with a history of asthma presents with an intensely itchy eruption on both hands associated with small, intensely itchy blisters on the lateral aspects of her fingers (figure).
She recently started a job as a dishwasher at a local restaurant. She does not have a rash anywhere else on her body, and no one at home has a similar rash.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Cephalexin 500 mg by mouth every 6 hours
Acyclovir 400 mg by mouth every 8 hours
5% topical permethrin cream applied once now and repeated in a week

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cephalexin is used to treat bacterial infections.

B) INCORRECT:

Acyclovir is the treatment for acute herpetic infection, such as herpes simplex virus or zoster, but a bilateral, acute, itchy rash in this clinical context is not consistent with that diagnosis.

C) CORRECT:

This patient has dyshidrotic eczema (also known as pompholyx), an acute, pruritic, vesicular eruption typically observed in patients with a history of atopic dermatitis or other forms of atopy, such as asthma and seasonal allergies. It often arises without provocation in atopic individuals and may also be exacerbated by repeated exposure to water, such as in dishwashers. The term ”dyshidrotic” is a misnomer as the condition has nothing to do with abnormal sweating; the vesicles are caused by intense epidermal spongiosis (intercellular edema). Lesions may occur anywhere on the hands or feet but are characteristically clustered on the lateral aspects of the digits and fingertips. The differential diagnosis includes the acute vesicular eruption of allergic contact dermatitis due to chemicals or other exposures.

Potent topical glucocorticoids, such as betamethasone dipropionate or clobetasol, are the treatment of choice in most patients with dyshidrotic eczema. The glucocorticoid can be applied regularly until the rash clears and then as needed. Vinyl gloves may be useful in the management of patients with dyshidrotic eczema who have frequent exposure to water. If irritant or contact dermatitis to vinyl gloves is suspected, cotton-lined vinyl gloves may be useful. Patch testing to identify potential contact allergens may be pursued.

Key learning point: An acute, pruritic, vesicular eruption that develops on the hands of a patient who works extensively with water is likely attributable to dyshidrotic eczema.

D) INCORRECT:

Five percent permethrin cream is a treatment for scabies, which is in the differential diagnosis of a vesicular hand dermatitis. This patient’s history, exposures, and lack of itchy rash elsewhere on the body make scabies less likely. If scabies is a concern, a scabies preparation observed with light microscopy should be performed in the clinic.

E) INCORRECT:

Mupirocin is used to treat bacterial infections.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old woman presents with pruritic skin lesions on her trunk and extremities. The lesions have been present for 2 months and did not improve with a 2-week course of 2% ketoconazole cream. The patient is otherwise healthy and takes no medications, although she reports having dry, sensitive skin in general.
On physical examination, she appears well overall. She has diffusely xerotic skin and approximately 10 coin-shaped, scaly patches and plaques on the trunk and extremities, each measuring about 2 cm in diameter (figure). Some of the lesions have foci of serous crusting and erosion.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Erythema multiforme is caused by an infectious agent (most often herpes simplex virus) or drug culprit and is characterized by three-zone target lesions with central duskiness, bullae, or erosion. The lesions often occur on acral sites, such as the palms and soles. Erythema multiforme may also manifest with mucosal involvement; it does not manifest with multiple itchy, scaly patches and plaques as depicted in this case.

B) INCORRECT:

Tinea corporis should be considered in any case that features round, scaly patches on the skin. However, this patient did not respond to topical ketoconazole, which adequately treats most dermatophyte skin infections. Ideally, clinicians should perform microscopic examination of skin scrapings (taken from the edge of a lesion and treated with potassium hydroxide [KOH]) to distinguish between tinea corporis and other inflammatory skin lesions such as nummular eczema.

C) INCORRECT:

Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (CTCL) may manifest with annular lesions, but the clinical context and appearance of the lesions in this case suggests eczema. CTCL may progress to plaques, nodules, and tumor formation.

D) CORRECT:

Nummular eczema is a subtype of eczema characterized by coin-shaped or annular scaly, patches and plaques that often feature dried serum and erosions. The lesions are often intensely pruritic. Potent topical glucocorticoids are first-line treatment, and prevention of new lesions with gentle skin care and daily emollients is recommended.

Key learning point: Coin-shaped pruritic lesions on the trunk and extremities of a patient with dry skin that have not responded to topical antifungal agents should prompt consideration of nummular eczema.

E) INCORRECT:

Psoriasis is characterized by thick, well-marginated plaques with silvery-white adherent scale. Although psoriasis may occur anywhere on the body, classic sites include the scalp, elbows, and knees. The clinical appearance and context differentiate it from eczema, which typically occurs in patients with an atopic diathesis.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man presents with a new rash on his hands and feet that appeared several weeks ago. His history is significant for severe acne that began several years ago and has been treated with oral isotretinoin for the past 6 months; two visits to the emergency department during the past 3 years for noncardiac chest pain; and a visit 4 weeks ago for pain, swelling, redness, and warmth of the medial right clavicle. Imaging and a bone biopsy at the recent visit revealed osteomyelitis, and the patient was treated empirically with vancomycin while culture results were pending; the vancomycin was stopped after the cultures remained negative for 3 weeks. On review of systems, the patient has had no fevers, chills, weight loss, or gastrointestinal symptoms but reports bilateral anterior knee pain.
Physical examination reveals inflammatory pustules and nodules admixed with scarring on the lateral neck and numerous pustules overlying the palms and soles surrounded by erythema and scale (figures 1 and 2); many of the discrete pustules have coalesced into plaques. The patient reports tenderness to palpation of the sternum, and there is a well-healing scar from his recent bone biopsy. He has pain at the insertion of the quadriceps tendon in both knees. The rest of the examination is within normal limits.
Laboratory results are notable for an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 36 mm/hr (reference range, 1–17) and a C-reactive protein level of 10 mg/liter (0.08–3.10). A comprehensive metabolic panel and complete blood count are within normal limits.
The microbial culture obtained from one of the pustules is sterile, and a potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation does not demonstrate hyphae. Skin biopsy reveals accumulation of neutrophils in the epidermis with surrounding hyperparakeratosis.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?

choices.text: SAPHO syndrome (synovitis, acne, pustulosis, hyperostosis, osteitis)
PAPA syndrome (pyogenic sterile arthritis, pyoderma gangrenosum, and acne)

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rocky Mountain spotted fever is a fairly acute process, occurring over several days to a week. Patients generally have a fever, headache, and myalgias. They usually start with a whole-body rash, but Rocky Mountain spotted fever (along with SAPHO, syphilis, and a few other unusual diseases) is one of the few systemic problems that can eventually cause a palmoplantar rash. It would not explain the sterile osteomyelitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Sweet syndrome (acute febrile neutrophilic dermatosis) can manifest with painful neutrophilic plaques and is associated with elevated inflammatory markers and, occasionally, arthritis. Fever is common but not necessary for diagnosis. However, the overall clinical picture in this case (in particular, the anterior chest wall symptoms and the time course) is more consistent with SAPHO syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Vancomycin and isotretinoin have been associated with acute generalized exanthematous pustulosis (AGEP). However, AGEP manifests as a diffuse pustular rash with flexural surface prominence that occurs several days after the exposure. The pattern and timeline of this patient’s symptoms are not consistent with AGEP, and this diagnosis would not explain his enthesitis.

D) CORRECT:

SAPHO syndrome (synovitis, acne, pustulosis, hyperostosis, osteitis) is an uncommon inflammatory syndrome that consists of several osteoarticular and cutaneous manifestations. The most common osteoarticular manifestations are sterile osteomyelitis, osteitis, and hyperostosis that affect the anterior chest wall and sternoclavicular joints. Affected patients may also develop synovitis or enthesitis (inflammation at the tendon-bone interface). Cutaneous findings — which may include severe acne, hidradenitis suppurativa, palmoplantar pustulosis, or pustular forms of psoriasis — may or may not coincide with osteoarticular manifestations. SAPHO syndrome should be considered in any patient with culture-negative osteomyelitis and palmoplantar pustulosis, especially if the condition is recurrent or associated with other osteoarticular or skin manifestations.

SAPHO syndrome has a bimodal distribution and can manifest in childhood with predominantly osteoarticular manifestations or in adulthood with both cutaneous and osteoarticular manifestations. There is no consensus on diagnostic criteria. However, all proposed criteria include a combination of osteoarticular symptoms and palmoplantar pustulosis. Quadriceps enthesitis is generally considered a minor criterion.

Key learning point: The constellation of culture-negative osteomyelitis and palmoplantar pustulosis, particularly if recurrent or in the setting of other osteoarticular or skin manifestations, should raise suspicion for SAPHO syndrome (synovitis, acne, pustulosis, hyperostosis, osteitis).

E) INCORRECT:

PAPA syndrome (pyogenic sterile arthritis, pyoderma gangrenosum, and acne) is an autosomal dominant inherited condition that usually manifests in childhood. This patient developed symptoms in his thirties and has no family history of similar symptoms, making this diagnosis unlikely. In addition, PAPA syndrome is not associated with palmar lesions.

questions.text:
A 14-year-old girl with a history of asthma presents with an intensely itchy eruption on both hands associated with small, intensely itchy blisters on the lateral aspects of her fingers (figure). She does not have a rash anywhere else on her body now, but she does have a history of atopic dermatitis during early childhood. No one else at home has a similar rash.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: 5% topical permethrin cream applied once now and repeated in a week
Acyclovir 400 mg by mouth every 8 hours
Cephalexin 500 mg by mouth every 6 hours

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mupirocin is used to treat bacterial infections, which would manifest as pustules.

B) INCORRECT:

Five percent permethrin cream is a treatment for scabies, which may manifest with vesicles on the hands. This patient’s history of atopy, the lack of itchy rash elsewhere on her body, and the acute appearance of innumerable monomorphic vesicles make scabies far less likely. If scabies is a concern, a scabies preparation observed with light microscopy should be performed in the clinic.

C) CORRECT:

This patient has dyshidrotic eczema (a form of hand eczema also known as pompholyx), an acute, pruritic, vesicular eruption typically observed in patients with a history of atopic dermatitis or other forms of atopy, such as asthma and seasonal allergies. It often arises without provocation in atopic individuals and may also be exacerbated by exposure to chemicals and repeated exposure to water. The term ”dyshidrotic” is a misnomer as the condition has nothing to do with abnormal sweating; the vesicles are caused by intense epidermal spongiosis (intercellular edema). Lesions may occur anywhere on the hands or feet but are characteristically clustered on the lateral aspects of the digits and fingertips. The primary differential diagnosis includes the acute vesicular eruption of allergic contact dermatitis due to plants, chemicals, or other exposures, and in the right clinical context, one could consider various viral infections such as herpes and coxsackie.

Potent topical glucocorticoids, such as clobetasol, are the treatment of choice in most patients with dyshidrotic eczema. The glucocorticoid can be applied regularly until the rash clears and then as needed. Emollients may be used between episodes. Patch testing to identify potential contact allergens may be pursued if allergic contact dermatitis is suspected as a cause of the eruption.

Key learning point: An acute, pruritic, vesicular eruption that develops on the hands of a patient with a history of atopy is likely attributable to dyshidrotic eczema.

D) INCORRECT:

Acyclovir is the treatment for acute herpetic infection, such as herpes simplex virus or zoster, but a bilateral, acute, itchy rash is much less consistent with that diagnosis. If herpes is suspected, a viral culture or herpes simplex virus polymerase chain-reaction test of vesicle fluid should be obtained.

E) INCORRECT:

Cephalexin is used to treat bacterial infections, which would manifest as pustules.

questions.text: A 12-month-old girl is brought to the office for a well-child examination. Her mother reports that she often does not respond to verbal instructions without pointing. She rarely babbles and has not started using specific sounds to refer to her mother or father. She can pull herself to a stand and pick up small objects using the pincer grasp. She drinks from an open cup with assistance. Her parents immigrated to the USA shortly after her birth. She has no history of severe medical illness and does not receive medications. Immunizations are up-to-date. She appears well. Physical examination shows a pale blue left iris, a dark brown right iris, and a patch of white hair on her forehead. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A defect in which of the following processes is most likely responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Impaired regulation of RAS GTPase activity is the pathomechanism of neurofibromatosis 1, which can manifest with intellectual disability and ocular abnormalities. However, pigmented iris hamartomas (Lisch nodules) and hyperpigmented café au lait spots on the skin are present rather than patchy hypopigmentation. Neurofibromatosis 1 typically manifests in adolescence.

B) INCORRECT:

Impaired transport of tyrosine to melanosomes is the pathomechanism of total albinism, which causes impaired melanin synthesis and manifests with hypopigmentation of the hair and irises. However, hypopigmentation typically affects all hair, both irises, and the skin. Hearing loss and secondary impaired language development are not expected in albinism.

C) CORRECT:

Waardenburg syndrome is an autosomal dominant inherited pigmentation disorder caused by abnormal differentiation of neural crest cells during embryogenesis, which leads to a patchy distribution of melanocytes. Congenital hearing loss is common and can impair language development. Other clinical features include a broad nasal root, cleft lip and cleft palate, neural tube defects, and an association with Hirschsprung disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Impaired synthesis of type 1 collagen is the pathomechanism of osteogenesis imperfecta, which can manifest with hearing loss and ocular abnormalities. However, the hearing loss is progressive rather than congenital, and the sclerae are usually blue. Heterochromia iridis and patchy depigmentation of the hair are not expected in osteogenesis imperfecta.

E) INCORRECT:

Impaired breakdown of gangliosides is the pathomechanism of lysosomal storage diseases, such as Tay-Sachs disease, which can manifest with developmental delay, ocular abnormalities, and auditory changes. However, developmental delay typically affects all areas of development. Additionally, ocular changes involve a cherry-red spot on the macula rather than patchy hypopigmentation, and auditory changes manifest as hyperacusis instead of congenital hearing loss.
questions.hint: Congenital hearing loss, heterochromia iridis, and patchy depigmentation of the hair are typical features of Waardenburg syndrome.

questions.text: A previously healthy 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 3-week history of fever, fatigue, and malaise. His mother says she noticed a significant decrease in his appetite and overall activity level. He is homeschooled and has had no sick contacts. There are no pets at home, but he often visits a feline animal shelter where his mother volunteers. Temperature is 38.4°C (101.2°F). Physical examination shows a 1-cm papular lesion on the back of the right hand. He also has tender, bulky lymphadenopathy of the axillae and groin. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antibiotic treatment with doxycycline is recommended for individuals with immunocompromise and localized CSD, and for most patients with extranodal CSD. This patient has localized CSD and does not have immunocompromise, so doxycycline is not the most appropriate antibiotic therapy. Additionally, if antibiotic treatment is necessary for a young child with extranodal CSD and/or immunocompromise, erythromycin should be considered instead of doxycycline to avoid its possible side effects (e.g., tooth enamel hypoplasia, permanent tooth discoloration).

B) INCORRECT:

Pyrimethamine is an antiprotozoal drug used in the treatment of toxoplasmosis, which is extremely rare in immunocompetent hosts. If symptoms occur, they are usually limited to painless, cervical lymphadenopathy, as opposed to the findings in this patient (papule on the hand, diffuse lymphadenopathy).

C) CORRECT:

Antibiotic treatment is usually not required in immunocompetent patients with localized CSD because the infection is self-limited. However, azithromycin can be used to reduce lymphadenopathy and illness duration. Treatment with erythromycin or doxycycline is recommended for individuals with immunocompromise and localized CSD and patients with extranodal CSD.
Image Description:

A solitary reddish-purple papule on an erythematous base is visible on the patient's right thenar eminence.

This appearance is typical of cat scratch disease, i.e., infection with Bartonella henselae.

D) INCORRECT:

Streptomycin is an aminoglycoside effective against Yersinia pestis, which is spread through flea bites and causes the plague. The most common subtype is bubonic plague, which also manifests with fever and weakness, followed by tender lymphadenopathy. Lymphadenopathy indicates that the infection has spread from the initial entry point on the hand throughout the body. In the case of plague, the presence of lymphadenopathy would indicate a severe and systemic course, often with gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., diarrhea, vomiting), followed by shock and multiple organ failure.

E) INCORRECT:

Itraconazole can be used for treating sporotrichosis caused by the fungus Sporothrix schenckii, which is usually transmitted through small skin lesions when handling soil or moss. The most common presentation is a papule that may ulcerate, usually without any systemic symptoms. In rare cases, sporotrichosis may spread to other organs such as the lungs and cause systemic symptoms, but this almost exclusively occurs in immunocompromised patients.
questions.hint: The cutaneous lesion on the patient's hand combined with bulky lymphadenopathy and a history of exposure to cats raises suspicion for localized cat scratch disease (CSD).

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the office because of fever and painful swelling in his right axilla for 1 week. He feels tired and reports a loss of appetite. He works in a garden center during weekdays and at a pet shop that sells various pet mammals and fish during the weekends. He smokes one pack of cigarettes daily and occasionally marijuana. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 95/min, and blood pressure is 131/85 mm Hg. Physical examination shows tender, erythematous, and fluctuant right axillary lymph node swelling with oozing purulent discharge. There is an erythematous papule on the right index finger. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely infectious agent?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Toxoplasma gondii is a parasite that is most commonly transmitted via the ingestion of cysts (e.g., from cat feces) and causes toxoplasmosis. Most immunocompetent individuals with toxoplasmosis are asymptomatic or have fever and lymphadenopathy, both of which are seen here. However, the adenopathy is typically nontender, bilateral, and affects the cervical lymph nodes, whereas this patient has unilateral, tender, suppurative, axillary lymphadenopathy. In addition, erythematous skin lesions are not characteristic of toxoplasmosis.

B) CORRECT:

Bartonella henselae is a gram‑negative bacterium that is commonly found in cats and transmitted to humans via a scratch or a bite. It can lead to a benign, self-limiting disease (i.e., cat-scratch disease) or disseminated disease in immunocompromised patients (i.e., bacillary angiomatosis). This patient's exposure to animals at the pet shop puts him at risk for developing cat-scratch disease, which initially manifests with fever, loss of appetite, and an erythematous, nontender cutaneous papule at the site of inoculation, all of which are seen here. Lymphadenopathy develops shortly after the initial symptoms, and is usually tender, unilateral, and localized near the site of the inoculation (most commonly in the axillary nodes).
Image Description:

A solitary reddish-purple papule on an erythematous base is visible on the patient's right thenar eminence.

This appearance is typical of cat scratch disease, i.e., infection with Bartonella henselae.

C) INCORRECT:

Vibrio vulnificus is a gram-negative bacillus that can be transmitted via contaminated seawater that has come into contact with open wounds. This patient's exposure to fish at the pet shop puts him at risk for developing a V. vulnificus infection, which can cause cellulitis and also manifest with an erythematous skin lesion, fever, and lymphadenopathy. However, suppuration of the lymph nodes is not characteristic of V. vulnificus cellulitis and the symptoms typically develop more acutely.

D) INCORRECT:

Pasteurella multocida is a gram‑negative coccobacillus that can cause cellulitis secondary to dog or cat bites. Although cellulitis might explain this patient's erythematous skin lesion, lymphadenopathy, and fever, it does not lead to suppuration of the lymph nodes and it typically manifests more acutely, making a different diagnosis more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Sporothrix schenckii is a dimorphic fungus that is found on vegetation and garden soil and leads to sporotrichosis, which initially manifests as an erythematous papule at the site of inoculation. However, most patients with sporotrichosis develop subcutaneous nodules and ulcers along the draining lymphatic vessels (nodular ascending lymphangitis) rather than isolated suppurative lymphadenopathy. In addition, sporotrichosis does not usually manifest with systemic symptoms such as fever and loss of appetite.
Image Description:

Photograph of the left arm of a patient

There are several large, nodular lesions on the left arm. The largest and most distal lesion is ulcerated. The chain-like pattern of these lesions follows a lymphocutaneous distribution.

This is the typical appearance of lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis.
questions.hint: Histopathological examination of the lesion will show necrotizing granulomas.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. He has had a progressively increasing swelling on the nape of the neck for 2 months. He has not had fever or any discharge from the swelling. He underwent a colectomy for colon cancer at 43 years of age. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and osteoarthritis. Current medications include insulin glargine, metformin, enalapril, and naproxen. He has worked as a landscaper for the past 16 years and frequently plays golf. He appears healthy. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 130/86 mm Hg. Examination of the neck shows a 2.5-cm firm, mobile, and painless nodule. The skin over the nodule cannot be pinched. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A photograph of the lesion is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Actinic keratoses (AK) are precancerous skin lesions caused by ultraviolet light exposure and are commonly found in light-skinned people over 50 years of age. AKs begin as a small lesion with a rough surface (“sandpaper-like texture”) and later grow to become scaly and crusted. These lesions can also transform into squamous cell carcinoma, a phenomenon particularly common in patients with multiple AKs. This patient's lesion does not have the typical appearance of an AK.
Image Description:

Frontal and parietal scalp of a male older adult

Multiple, partially confluent, hyperpigmented and hypopigmented macules of different size are visible. Some of these lesions have scaling, and some are covered in yellow to black-brown crusts.

These findings are characteristic of actinic keratosis.

B) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is consistent with an epidermoid cyst, a nontender, dome-shaped, slow-growing nodule that arises from the epidermis and contains keratin. Common locations for epidermoid cysts include the neck, face, head, back, and genital area. These lesions can be distinguished from those arising below the epidermis, as the overlying skin cannot be pinched.

C) INCORRECT:

Dermatofibromas are small, skin-colored growths that most commonly develop on the lower extremities. Because dermatofibromas arise from the dermis, the epidermis overlying the lesion is pinchable and produces a central dimple (Fitzpatrick sign). Since the skin overlying this patient's nodule cannot be pinched, it is unlikely to be a dermatofibroma.
Image Description:

A solitary, pigmented, firm circular lesion is visible. Upon pinching of the lesion, the overlaying skin retracts inwards (dimple sign).

This appearance is suggestive of a dermatofibroma, which usually manifests as a nodule.

D) INCORRECT:

Lipomas are painless, slow-growing, mobile nodules that are rubbery rather than firm (they are made of mature fat cells). Unlike this patient's nodule, lipomas do not arise from the cutaneous layers; the overlying skin can be pinched.
Image Description:

There is a solitary soft subcutaneous nodule under normal-appearing skin. If the nodule is pushed by gently sliding a finger over the edge, the lipoma tends to slip away from the examining finger (slippage/slip sign).

E) INCORRECT:

Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is the second most common skin cancer after basal cell carcinoma. The classic presentation of SCC is a painless, slow-growing, nonhealing ulcer with everted edges. The underlying structure that ulcerates can range from plaque-like to verrucous. Although a potential malignancy must be considered, this patient's nonulcerated nodule does not fit the classic presentation of SCC.
Image Description:

A solitary ulcer, approx. 2 cm in diameter, is visible on the lower lip. The inferior aspect of the ulcer appears hyperkeratotic.

This finding is highly suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma. Oral squamous cell carcinoma most commonly affects the lower lip because of its direct exposure to sunlight.
questions.hint: This patient's nodule arises from the layers of the skin, as it cannot be pinched.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman comes to the office because of multiple skin lesions over her legs for one month. She reports that the lesions are red, dry, and intensely pruritic. She has had 3 episodes in the past 2 years with similar lesions that resolved spontaneously after a couple of months. She mentions that she has been using a moisturizer daily because of her dry skin. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable and she takes no medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. A photograph of one of the lesions is shown. Gram stain of a skin swab of the lesion and skin scraping for fungal hyphae are negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Nummular eczema (NE) is a chronic, relapsing inflammatory skin condition characterized by multiple well-demarcated, round, dry, and intensely pruritic erythematous plaques typically affecting the extremities. NE is thought to be caused by an immunological hypersensitivity reaction due to xerosis and damage to the epidermal lipid barrier, but the pathogenesis is not completely understood. Patient history, clinical examination findings, and negative skin scrapings for mycology are sufficient to confirm the diagnosis of NE. Management includes measures to help prevent dry skin (e.g., application of moisturizer, use of mild soaps) and topical anti-inflammatory agents (e.g., corticosteroids, tacrolimus, pimecrolimus).

B) INCORRECT:

Allergic contact dermatitis (ACD) can manifest with pruritic and erythematous plaques as a result of a delayed hypersensitivity reaction after exposure to certain substances, e.g., moisturizer, which this patient has reported using. In ACD, however, all areas of skin exposed to the allergen are typically involved.
Image Description:

Upper body of a man presenting with a severely pruritic rash after getting a henna tattoo on the right arm

An erythematous papulovesicular rash is visible over the chest and arms. The rash is most severe around the henna tattoo, which appears markedly erythematous.

This is the typical appearance of allergic contact dermatitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Atopic dermatitis (AD) is a chronic, relapsing inflammatory skin condition that may manifest with dry, pruritic, and erythematous plaques. However, the plaques seen in adult patients with AD are typically distributed along the flexural creases (e.g., cubital fossa, popliteal fossa). Moreover, most cases of AD develop before the age of 5 years, and patients with AD often have a history of asthma or allergic rhinitis.
Image Description:

Ill-defined, erythematous macules with excoriation (due to scratching) can be seen on the flexural surface of the knee.

D) INCORRECT:

Psoriasis is a chronic, relapsing inflammatory skin condition that can manifest with multiple, well-demarcated, pruritic, erythematous plaques. However, the plaques seen in psoriasis are usually not limited to the legs. Moreover, psoriasis plaques are typically associated with silvery-white scaling, which this patient does not have.
Image Description:

Extensor (dorsal) surface of the right forearm

Multiple well-demarcated, partially confluent, erythematous plaques with silver-white scaling are visible.

These patches are characteristic of plaque psoriasis, which typically occurs on extensor surfaces of the body.

E) INCORRECT:

Tinea corporis (TC) is a dermatophytic infection that can manifest with ring-shaped, pruritic, erythematous plaques. However, a skin scraping for mycology would reveal fungal hyphae. Moreover, TC does not typically resolve spontaneously, like this patient's previous episodes. Instead, topical antifungal treatment (e.g., miconazole, terbinafine) is usually required. Additionally, TC plaques are typically associated with central clearing and raised borders.
Image Description:

A round, well demarcated erythematous lesion with central scaling is visible. The border is raised with several pustules visible.

These features are characteristic of tinea corporis.
questions.hint: The photograph shows a 5 cm coin-shaped, erythematous scaly plaque.

questions.text: A 31-year-old man comes to the office because of a 1-week history of a bilateral pruritic rash on his hands and fingers. He says that he has had a similar rash several times during the past few years, mostly in late spring and summer. The previous rashes resolved spontaneously several weeks later with peeling skin. He has a history of dermatophyte infection of the feet, which was successfully treated with topical terbinafine. A photograph of his right index finger is shown. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hand eczema, which may be a manifestation of atopic dermatitis, usually causes severe pruritus. However, atopic hand eczema typically manifests as diffuse erythema and scaling on the dorsum of the hands, and is chronic rather than recurrent. In addition, this patient has no history of atopic dermatitis, allergy, or asthma, making atopic hand eczema unlikely.
Image Description:

Erythematous papules are visible on the dorsal aspect of the fingers and knuckles.

These findings are consistent with contact dermatitis or atopic dermatitis.

B) INCORRECT:

While palmoplantar pustulosis can manifest with recurrent, pruritic lesions on both hands, the lesions are pustular rather than vesicular, mostly affect the palms, and are usually also present on the soles of the feet. Moreover, the pustules in palmoplantar pustulosis usually dry and desquamate within days rather than weeks, resulting in hyperkeratosis and brown macules.

C) INCORRECT:

Tinea manuum is a dermatophyte infection of the hands that can cause recurrent episodes of pruritus. However, tinea manuum is typically unilateral and manifests with a dry, erythematous, and scaly palmar surface, and/or a round, erythematous plaque on the dorsum of the hand (vesicles and bullae may be present in some cases). Moreover, in most cases, tinea manuum occurs at the same time as tinea pedis (“two feet-one hand syndrome”), and while this patient has a history of tinea pedis, it is not currently present.
Image Description:

Localization: palm of the right hand

Lesion: dry skin, hyperkeratosis, and rhagades, particularly in the hand lines. Lesions usually start on one hand, but may spread to the other side.

Differential diagnosis: atopic eczema, palmoplantar eczema, psoriasis, and allergic contact dermatitis

D) CORRECT:

Dyshidrotic eczema is a condition of unknown etiology that is characterized by recurrent episodes of vesicular and/or bullous eruptions on the palms, sides of the fingers, and/or soles. Symptoms are often exacerbated by warm weather. The deep-seated vesicles and bullae typically persist for several weeks and then resolve with drying and desquamation. A history of dermatophyte infection, as seen in this patient, is a risk factor for dyshidrotic eczema; additional risk factors include atopic dermatitis, irritant contact dermatitis, and allergic contact dermatitis. Chronic dermatitis and secondary infection are potential complications.

Dyshidrotic eczema is typically managed using general measures (e.g., avoiding triggers, appropriate skin care); topical corticosteroids are used in mild cases that do not respond to general measures, and oral corticosteroids are used in severe cases.

E) INCORRECT:

While recurrent episodes of finger edema and vesicular eruptions are typical features of herpetic whitlow, the lesions seen in this condition are typically unilateral and painful rather than pruritic. In addition, symptoms such as fever and malaise are often present in herpetic whitlow, both of which are absent in this patient.
Image Description:

A cluster of three nonpurulent vesicles on an erythematous base is visible on the distal phalanx. The surrounding skin is intact.

This is the characteristic appearance of herpetic whitlow.
questions.hint: This patient has a recurrent, bilateral, pruritic vesicular rash affecting the hands and fingers. Although this patient's condition is usually self-limited, treatment with corticosteroids may be considered.

questions.text: A previously healthy 1-month-old girl is brought to the office by her parents because of a rash in the axillae and on the neck and trunk for the past day. She has had no fever, runny nose, vomiting, or diarrhea. Two days ago, the family arrived in Miami to introduce the girl to her grandparents during the summer vacation. The parents report that they dressed her in several layers of clothing to protect her from direct sun exposure. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. A photograph of the rash is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antihistamines (e.g., diphenhydramine) can be used to treat type I hypersensitivity reactions, which result in histamine release and can manifest with a pruritic, erythematous, papular rash. However, miliaria rubra is not histamine-mediated, so an antihistamine would not be appropriate.

B) INCORRECT:

Reassurance alone is appropriate for self-limited, asymptomatic rashes. However, this patient's rash is making her uncomfortable, and she would benefit from intervention to encourage resolution of the rash and prevention of its recurrence.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral acetaminophen can be used to treat fever or pain. This patient has not had any fever, and her discomfort is likely due to pruritus from miliaria rubra, which does not respond to treatment with acetaminophen.

D) INCORRECT:

Topical nystatin can be used to treat cutaneous candidiasis, which can manifest with an erythematous rash in the diaper or intertriginous areas after prolonged exposure to moisture. However, candidal intertrigo typically manifests with maceration, vesicles and pustules that easily rupture, and satellite lesions. Miliaria rubra does not have a fungal origin, so antifungal therapy is not indicated.

E) CORRECT:

Miliaria is often seen in hot and humid climates (e.g., Miami) and can occur in all ages but commonly affects children and infants. Miliaria rubra is the most prevalent form of miliaria and manifests with a pruritic, papulovesicular, erythematous rash, typically on the intertriginous areas of the groin, axillae, and neck. Management of miliaria rubra consists of measures to reduce sweating and occlusion of eccrine glands, such as keeping the patient in a cool environment, wearing breathable clothing (e.g., cotton), lightly scrubbing the skin to remove debris that can clog sweat glands, and, if nonpharmacologic measures fail to reduce the rash, administering topical steroids to decrease inflammation.
questions.hint: This patient developed an erythematous, papular rash after arriving in a hot and humid climate, which is characteristic of miliaria rubra.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman comes to your clinic with multiple skin lesions on her legs for the past month. She describes the lesions as red, dry, and intensely pruritic. She has had three similar episodes in the past two years, each resolving spontaneously after a couple of months. She has been using a moisturizer daily for dry skin. Her medical history is unremarkable and she does not take any medications. Vital signs are normal. A photograph of one of the lesions is provided. Gram stain of a skin swab and skin scraping for fungal hyphae are negative. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Nummular eczema (NE) is a chronic, relapsing inflammatory skin condition characterized by multiple well-demarcated, round, dry, and intensely pruritic erythematous plaques typically affecting the extremities. NE is thought to be caused by an immunological hypersensitivity reaction due to xerosis and damage to the epidermal lipid barrier, but the pathogenesis is not completely understood. Patient history, clinical examination findings, and negative skin scrapings for mycology are sufficient to confirm the diagnosis of NE. Management includes measures to help prevent dry skin (e.g., application of moisturizer, use of mild soaps) and topical anti-inflammatory agents (e.g., corticosteroids, tacrolimus, pimecrolimus).

Key learning point: Nummular eczema presents as chronic, relapsing, well-demarcated, round, dry, and intensely pruritic erythematous plaques, most commonly on the extremities, and is managed with moisturizers and topical anti-inflammatory agents.

B) INCORRECT:

Tinea corporis (TC) is a dermatophytic infection that can manifest with ring-shaped, pruritic, erythematous plaques. However, a skin scraping for mycology would reveal fungal hyphae. Moreover, TC does not typically resolve spontaneously, like this patient's previous episodes. Instead, topical antifungal treatment (e.g., miconazole, terbinafine) is usually required. Additionally, TC plaques are typically associated with central clearing and raised borders.

C) INCORRECT:

Allergic contact dermatitis (ACD) can manifest with pruritic and erythematous plaques as a result of a delayed hypersensitivity reaction after exposure to certain substances, e.g., moisturizer, which this patient has reported using. In ACD, however, all areas of skin exposed to the allergen are typically involved.

D) INCORRECT:

Psoriasis is a chronic, relapsing inflammatory skin condition that can manifest with multiple, well-demarcated, pruritic, erythematous plaques. However, the plaques seen in psoriasis are usually not limited to the legs. Moreover, psoriasis plaques are typically associated with silvery-white scaling, which this patient does not have.

E) INCORRECT:

Atopic dermatitis (AD) is a chronic, relapsing inflammatory skin condition that may manifest with dry, pruritic, and erythematous plaques. However, the plaques seen in adult patients with AD are typically distributed along the flexural creases (e.g., cubital fossa, popliteal fossa). Moreover, most cases of AD develop before the age of 5 years, and patients with AD often have a history of asthma or allergic rhinitis.
questions.hint: The photograph shows a 5 cm coin-shaped, erythematous scaly plaque.

questions.text: You are seeing a previously healthy 5-year-old boy who is brought to your clinic by his mother because of a 3-week history of fever, fatigue, and malaise. His mother reports a significant decrease in his appetite and activity level. He is homeschooled and has had no known sick contacts. There are no pets at home, but he frequently visits a feline animal shelter where his mother volunteers. His temperature is 38.4°C. On examination, there is a 1-cm papular lesion on the back of his right hand. He has tender, bulky lymphadenopathy in the axillae and groin. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Antibiotic treatment is usually not required in immunocompetent patients with localized CSD because the infection is self-limited and resolves within 6 months. However, azithromycin can be used to reduce lymphadenopathy and illness duration. Treatment with erythromycin or doxycycline is recommended for individuals with immunocompromise and localized CSD, and for patients with extranodal CSD.

Key learning point: Cat scratch disease is a self-limited disease in immunocompetent patients, but azithromycin can reduce lymphadenopathy and illness duration.
Image Description:

A solitary reddish-purple papule on an erythematous base is visible on the patient's right thenar eminence.

This appearance is typical of cat scratch disease, i.e., infection with Bartonella henselae.

B) INCORRECT:

Pyrimethamine is an antiprotozoal drug used in the treatment of toxoplasmosis, which is extremely rare in immunocompetent hosts. If symptoms occur, they are usually limited to painless, cervical lymphadenopathy, as opposed to the findings in this patient (papule on the hand, diffuse lymphadenopathy).

C) INCORRECT:

Streptomycin is an aminoglycoside effective against Yersinia pestis, which is spread through flea bites and causes the plague. The most common subtype is bubonic plague, which also manifests with fever and weakness, followed by tender lymphadenopathy. Lymphadenopathy indicates that the infection has spread from the initial entry point on the hand throughout the body. However, plague is exceedingly rare, and plague has a very rapid onset and a fulminant course; high fever, chills, prostration, and painful buboes typically develop within days of exposure, whereas this boy has had a low-grade fever for three weeks.

D) INCORRECT:

Antibiotic treatment with doxycycline is recommended for individuals with immunocompromise and localized CSD, and for most patients with extranodal CSD. This patient has localized CSD and does not have immunocompromise, so doxycycline is not the most appropriate antibiotic therapy. Additionally, if antibiotic treatment is necessary for a young child with extranodal CSD and/or immunocompromise, erythromycin should be considered instead of doxycycline to avoid its possible side effects (e.g., tooth enamel hypoplasia, permanent tooth discoloration).

E) INCORRECT:

Itraconazole can be used for treating sporotrichosis caused by the fungus Sporothrix schenckii, which is usually transmitted through small skin lesions when handling soil or moss. The most common presentation is a papule that may ulcerate, usually without any systemic symptoms. In rare cases, sporotrichosis may spread to other organs such as the lungs and cause systemic symptoms, but this almost exclusively occurs in immunocompromised patients.
questions.hint: The cutaneous lesion on the patient's hand combined with bulky lymphadenopathy and a history of exposure to cats raises suspicion for localized cat scratch disease (CSD).
